prompt: <description>**Part 1: Construct a 3D model of a rectangular prism with a curved top and a flat bottom.** Begin by creating a new coordinate system for part 1 with the following properties: - Euler Angles: (0.0, 0.0, -90.0) - Translation Vector: (0.0, 0.0375, 0.0) Next, create the 2D sketch for face 1 with the following closed loop (loop_1) and lines: - Line 1: (0.0, 0.0) to (0.1641, 0.0) - Line 2: (0.1641, 0.0) to (0.1828, 0.1875) - Line 3: (0.1828, 0.1875) to (0.2109, 0.0) - Line 4: (0.2109, 0.0) to (0.3656, 0.0) - Line 5: (0.3656, 0.0) to (0.3096, 0.3737) - Line 6: (0.3096, 0.3737) to (0.3656, 0.75) - Line 7: (0.3656, 0.75) to (0.2062, 0.75) - Line 8: (0.2062, 0.75) to (0.1828, 0.5625) - Line 9: (0.1828, 0.5625) to (0.1594, 0.75) - Line 10: (0.1594, 0.75) to (0.0, 0.75) - Line 11: (0.0, 0.75) to (0.0376, 0.376) - Line 12: (0.0376, 0.376) to (0.0, 0.0) Scale the 2D sketch by a factor of 0.75. Transform the scaled 2D sketch into a 3D sketch using the euler angles and translation vector from the coordinate system. Extrude the 3D sketch by 0.0375 units along the normal vector. The completed part 1 has the following dimensions: - Length: 0.75 units - Width: 0.0375 units - Height: 0.8037 units **Part 2: Construct a CAD model of a cylindrical object with three rectangular cutouts.** Begin by creating a new coordinate system for part 2 with the following properties: - Euler Angles: (0.0, 0.0, 0.0) - Translation Vector: (0.0508, 0.0164, 0.75) Create the 2D sketch for face 1 with the following closed loop (loop_1) and circle: - Circle 1: Center (0.0023, 0.0023), Radius: 0.0023 Repeat the process for faces 2 through 4 with the following circles: - Face 2: Center (0.0554, 0.0023), Radius: 0.0023 - Face 3: Center (0.2087, 0.0023), Radius: 0.0023 - Face 4: Center (0.2618, 0.0023), Radius: 0.0023 Note that the circles along each face form a rectangular cutout. Scale the 2D sketch by a factor of 0.2641. Transform the scaled 2D sketch into a 3D sketch using the euler angles and translation vector from the coordinate system. Extrude the 3D sketch by -0.0375 units along the inverse normal vector. The completed part 2 has the following dimensions: - Length: 0.2641 units - Width: 0.</description>

prompt: <description>**Part 1: Flat, Circular Object with a Central Hole** Begin by creating a new coordinate system with no rotation or translation. This will be the base for our first part. Create a new sketch on the X-Y plane of the coordinate system. Draw three concentric circles on the sketch, with radii of 0.375, 0.2297, and 0.2062 respectively. Label them as circle_1, circle_2, and circle_3. These circles define the faces of the part. Each face consists of one loop. The first loop (loop_1) is on face_1 and is made up of circle_1. The second loop (loop_2) is on face_1 as well and is made up of circle_2. Similarly, the third loop (loop_3) is on face_2 and is made up of circle_2, and the fourth loop (loop_4) is on face_2 and is made up of circle_3. After creating the loops, scale the sketch by a factor of 0.75. Extrude the sketch along the normal vector by a distance of 0.0281 units. Use the "NewBodyFeatureOperation" for the extrusion operation. The final dimensions of this part are 0.75 units in length, width, and height. **Part 2: Cylindrical Object with a Slightly Tapered Top** Create a new coordinate system with no rotation. Translate it by (0.1453, 0.1453, 0) relative to the previous coordinate system. Create a new sketch on the X-Y plane of the new coordinate system. Draw two concentric circles on the sketch, with radii of 0.2297 and 0.2062 respectively. Label them as circle_1 and circle_2. These circles define the faces of the part. Each face consists of one loop. The first loop (loop_1) is on face_1 and is made up of circle_1. The second loop (loop_2) is on face_1 as well and is made up of circle_2. After creating the loops, scale the sketch by a factor of 0.4594. Extrude the sketch along the normal vector by a distance of 0.2812 units. Use the "JoinFeatureOperation" for the extrusion operation. The final dimensions of this part are approximately 0.4594 units in length and width, and 0.2812 units in height. **Part 3: Cylindrical Object with a Slightly Tapered Top** Create a new coordinate system with no rotation or translation. This will be the base for our third part. Create a new sketch on the X-Y plane of the coordinate system. Draw two concentric circles on the sketch, with radii of 0.375 and 0.2297 respectively. Label them as circle_1 and circle_2. These circles define the faces of the part. Each face consists of one loop. The first loop (loop_1) is on face_1 and is made up of circle_1. The second loop (loop_2) is on face_1 as well and is made up of circle_2. After creating the loops, scale the sketch by a factor of 0.75. Extrude the sketch along the normal vector by a distance of 0.0281 units. Use the "JoinFeatureOperation" for the extrusion operation. The final dimensions of this part are 0.75 units in length, width, and height. **Final Shape: Cylindrical Object with a Flat Top and Bottom** Combine the three parts using the appropriate boolean operation to create the final shape. The flat top and bottom are circular, while the curved section is oval-shaped. The object is symmetrical along its central axis. The final dimensions of the shape are approximately 0.75 units in length and width, and 0.3093 units in height.</description>

<description>Part 1: Creating a Circular Object with Evenly Spaced Holes First, construct a coordinate system with the given Euler angles and translation vector. Sketching the Base: 1. Create circle_1 on face_8 with its center at (0.3581, 0.1644) and a radius of 0.0234. 6. Create circle_1 on face_9 with its center at (0.3752, 0.3027) and a radius of 0.0234. Part 2: Creating a Rectangular Prism with a Centered Circular Hole 1. Start by creating a coordinate system aligning with the global referential. 2. Sketch a rectangle on the XY plane with its corners at (0.0, 0.0) and (0.75, 0.6866), which forms face_1. 3. Draw a circle centered at (0.375, 0.3433) with a radius of 0.0406, which intersects the rectangle. Cut everything outside the circle. 4. Scale the resulting 3D geometry by a factor of 0.75. With these instructions, the junior CAD designer will be able to create the desired CAD assembly according to the given JSON.</description>

Finally, extrude the 2D sketch to generate a 3D model with a depth of 0.0045 units towards the normal, and a depth of 0 units towards the opposite direction of the normals. The sketch scale should be 0.75. The resulting prism will have a length of 0.75 units, a width of 0.0045 units, and a height of 0.75 units. Final Shape Instructions Shape The final shape is a three-dimensional rectangular prism with a flat top and bottom. The sides of the prism are parallel and meet at right angles. The dimensions of the prism are 2 units by 3 units by 4 units. Instructions The final shape can be constructed by following the instructions provided for Part 1. prompt: <description>**Part 1: Construct a 3D model of a rectangular prism with two circular holes on opposite sides** **Step 1: Create a new coordinate system** Create a new coordinate system with the following properties: * Euler Angles: [0.0, 0.0, -90.0] * Translation Vector: [0.0, 0.0964, 0.0] **Step 2: Draw the 2D sketch** Draw a 2D sketch on the X-Y plane of the new coordinate system. **Step 3: Create the first face and loop** Create a new face and loop with the following curves: * Line 1: Start Point [0.0, 0.0], End Point [0.75, 0.0] * Line 2: Start Point [0.75, 0.0], End Point [0.75, 0.3651] * Line 3: Start Point [0.75, 0.3651], End Point [0.0, 0.3651] * Line 4: Start Point [0.0, 0.3651], End Point [0.0, 0.0] This will create a rectangular shape with a width of 0.75 units and a height of 0.3651 units. **Step 4: Create the first circular hole** Create a new loop with a circular shape: * Circle: Center [0.2814, 0.2181], Radius 0.1042 This will create a circular hole with a diameter of 0.2084 units located at the center of the rectangular shape. **Step 5: Create the second circular hole** Create a new loop with the following curves: * Line 1: Start Point [0.4427, 0.2233], End Point [0.4979, 0.0938] * Line 2: Start Point [0.4979, 0.0938], End Point [0.6381, 0.1062] * Line 3: Start Point [0.6381, 0.1062], End Point [0.6696, 0.2434] * Line 4: Start Point [0.6696, 0.2434], End Point [0.5489, 0.3158] * Line 5: Start Point [0.5489, 0.3158], End Point [0.4427, 0.2233] This will create a complex shape with a diameter of approximately 0.2 units. **Step 6: Scale the 2D sketch** Scale the 2D sketch using a scaling factor of 0.75. **Step 7: Transform the scaled 2D sketch into 3D Sketch** Transform the scaled 2D sketch into a 3D sketch using the euler angles and translation vector of the coordinate system. **Step 8: Extrude the 3D model** Extrude the 3D model with a depth of 0.0964 units towards the normal and no depth opposite the normal. **Congratulations! You have successfully constructed the final 3D model of a rectangular prism with two circular holes on opposite sides.** **Model Details:** * The 3D model has a length of approximately 0.75 units, a width of 0.0964 units, and a height of approximately 0.75 units. * The circular holes have a diameter of 0.2084 units and are located at the center of the rectangular shape.</description>
